To test this idea, we could randomly select a sample of offspring from this cross and count the number of appearances of Blue and Green. If the offspring distribution is closer to 3/4 Blue and 1/4 Green than we would expect if inheritance were solely based on dominant and recessive genes, then we have evidence that dominance is indeed playing a role in this system.

In this problem, we have a population of beetles with three possible wing colors: blue, green, and turquoise. Each beetle in the population represents an individual with its own unique set of genes. The goal is to find the best possible solution to the problem, which is a population of beetles with the highest average wing color.

To start the genetic algorithm, we'll need to define the fitness function that will be used to evaluate the quality of each individual in the population. In this case, the fitness function will be the average wing color of the population.

The genetic algorithm will then use this fitness function to select individuals for reproduction. The selected individuals will be crossed with each other to create new offspring. The offspring will inherit pieces of their parents' genes, and the genetic algorithm will use this process of mutation and crossover to evolve the population over time.

In this step, we'll use a two-way crossover operation to create new offspring. The parents will be selected randomly from the population, and their genes will be combined to create two new offspring. The offspring will then inherit a mixture of genes from their parents, which will help to introduce variability into the population.

We'll also use a one-way mutation operation to modify the genes of some individuals in the population. Each mutation will introduce a new type of gene into the population, which can result in some individuals having a different set of wing colors than others.

Finally, the offspring will be evaluated again using the fitness function, and the genetic algorithm will repeat this process of selection, crossover, and mutation until a best-possible solution is found. The best- Possible solution will be the population of beetles with the highest average wing color.

prompt.content:
One type of beetle has 3 possible wing colors, blue, green and turquoise. Randomly caught individuals of a polymorphic population were crossed with each other.
It is a monohybrid inheritance with three alleles, B, G & T. Dominance: B > G > T
You get the parent phenotype, and the distribution of phenotypes in the F1 - generation. State the genotypes of the parents and offspring as accurately as possible. No further explanation necessary. If a given distribution is impossible, state 'impossible'.
Example task:
Blue x Blue -> 4/4 Blue
Example solution:
BB (Blue) x B_ (Blue) -> 4/4 B_ (Blue)
Example Task:
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Green
Example Solution:
BG (Blue) x BG (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BG (Green), 1/4 GG (Green)
Blue x Blue -> 3/4 Blue 1/4 Turquoise

options: BT (Blue) x BT (Blue) -> 1/4 BB (Blue), 1/2 BT (Blue), 1/4 TT (Turquoise)
